result.adr_address: 5439 Ballard Ave NW, Seattle, WA 98107-4052, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Longtime venue offering a relaxed eatery for classic American mains & a low-key bar section.

result.formatted_address: 5439 Ballard Ave NW, Seattle, WA 98107, USA
result.name: The Ballard Smoke Shop

reviews.text: My favorite place to go after work! Such a wonderful vibe, good games, music isn't so loud that I can't talk with my friends. Kerry and Drew are such nice bartenders and they always make me feel welcomed. Tater tots are great too!

Cozy local dive with a pretty nice selection of arcade games. Typical bar food with a focus on fried chicken it seems (didn't try any, but we will be back). The bartender was nice and the prices were fair.

Good food, good booze, great little dive bar with a lot of history. They were serving house made buckets of chicken, made me salivate but didn't get one because my friends had other food plans, but darn! Buckets of fried chicken!
The Ballard smoke shop is a staple. Nothing quite like it. Great place for cheap beer and good laughs.

Drew is always an awesome bartender to have! Really takes the time to take care of everyone on chaotic nights. Carrie is also a treasure, remembers every detail of a patron down to their seat and drink. The staff is dynamite!

The Ballard Smoke Shop.description: Recently yoinked back from the cliffs of extinction by Sunset Tavern owner Max Genereaux, the Smoke Shop is a precious diner/dive combo that really exemplifies the grotty blue-collar spirit of Old Seattle. Genereaux gave the dining room a fresh paint job, some new booths and pinball machines, and a menu update — including a Jucy Lucy! — but the ‘30s-era bar has pretty much stayed its crusty old self. (The giant king crab is still on the wall, mercifully.) The late-night menu runs until midnight on weeknights and 1 a.m. on weekends, and they’ve got Evan on well.

result.adr_address: 5231 Ballard Ave NW, Seattle, WA 98107-4809, USA

editorial_summary.overview: This longtime local cafe offers 3 meals a day plus drinks & live events in funky down-home digs.

result.formatted_address: 5231 Ballard Ave NW, Seattle, WA 98107, USA
result.name: Hattie's Hat Restaurant

reviews.text: Such a unique place for brunch in Downtown Ballard. The food was so delicious that it made the 20min wait worth it. Luckily they text you updates and when the table is available, so we enjoyed walking around the Ballard Farmers Market. Had the Austin Scramble and an Everything Bagel with Cream Cheese 🤤. Definitely coming back!

Food was pretty good!!
Self seating is nice and service arrived pretty fast, as well as food and drinks once ordered.
Nice place to get breakfast any time of the day, mimosas all day too 😭.
Prices were adequate for the quality as well, around $60 for two people with drinks.
Would definitely come back!

Great spot, customer service, drinks, prices, and brunch. Comfortable outside seating with mini fireplaces.

I have come in at different times (anywhere from 1pm on a Saturday, to 10pm on Thursday) and have been seated within 10 minutes of walking up.

Tasty brunch- eggs Benedict (ham meat option), and chicken fried chicken breakfast (the gravy was delicious, the chicken fried chicken was flavorful and crispy).

The food are good and survive is friendly! We ordered hippie scramble and max wich.  Hippie scramble is good. The side is zucchini scramble eggs, it’s light but tasty, I like it. If you don’t wanna eat a full meal, maybe max wich is a good option. It’s a burger with cream cheese, an egg, and bacon. It tasty as well. For the drink, we order a jar of peach mimosa. It’s okay but more like an orange mimosa 😅

I was kindly greeted by the host and was told to select my seat. It wasn’t super packed on a Monday morning. The waitress was kind, patient and attentive. They have many hot sauces! The waitress kindly made sure my food was diary-free and made that part easy. The hash browns were somewhat crisp and a kind of mash which made for them to be flavorful not oily or gross like some restaurants. The toast was standard diner style and good. The bacon was thick and the scramble had generous ingredients. Great experience! Music was a style I liked. It was easy for me to work for an hour too. Ladro coffee available! So, I’ll be back! Thank you!

Hattie's Hat Restaurant.description: Hattie’s is like your cozy but stylish vintage sweater that somehow goes with everything. You can sidle up to the gorgeous mahogany bar and sip Bill Murray cocktails with a date you wanna impress or grab one of the wooden antique booths on the restaurant side and have a casual diner meal with your friends. It’s open for breakfast at 9 a.m. on weekends, so you can nurse a hangover here just as easily as you acquired it. And the crowd spans generations, like all the best bars’ crowds do.

result.adr_address: 119 N 36th St, Seattle, WA 98103, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Clever cocktails & dumplings served in a hip, snug space with a tin ceiling & patio lit by lanterns.

result.name: Stampede Cocktail Club

reviews.text: the drinks are beautifully crafted and tasteful. incredible atmosphere and ambiance. the jewel on the crown is their veggie dumplings, absolutely delicious just couldn't stop ordering them!!

Amazing cocktails all around! Huge menu and pretty much all the ones I tried were hits. They were very unique. And great vibes in the restaurant as well. We sat outside and the heaters were strong so kept us warm. We also got the dumplings which were delicious.

I enjoy stampede. It's a bit more mellow with softer lights and it can be much more intimate than the other places along Fremont. The wait staff has been polite and helpful when it's needed.

I think this is a great place for outdoor dining or indoor. They have covered patio to shield yourself from the chilled rain. They have a specialty cocktail menu, and I enjoyed their michelada special with a tequila shot on the side. I would highly recommend!

Stampede is one of my favorite cocktail bars in Seattle. All of their cocktails have something unusual, which makes them interesting and fun to drink.

They have a video game themed menu loaded with entertaining jokes. The jungle themed interior is next-level – and don’t miss the decorating in the bathrooms either!

Stampede has ample outdoor seating with space heaters. So if you’re looking for a warm area with good airflow, make a trip out to Stampede!

This place is very cool. The atmosphere is great, the server was incredibly friendly. Awesome drinks. Plus the menu was so fun. It was great for getting a drink alone while traveling but would also be a fun date night spot. The painkiller was excellent.

Stampede Cocktail Club.description: Stampede makes some of the most inventive drinks in the city, and the bar excels equally at no-alcohol options as it does cocktails. The approach is as playful as it is crafty: tiki-adjacent with a wide palette. Colorful lanterns give the bar area a deep glow, while cool neon in the adjoining room give vaporwave and Patrick Nagel vibes. It’s like a party at an edgy art gallery only the guests will actually talk to you.

result.adr_address: 707 E Pine St, Seattle, WA 98122-2234, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Cowboy-themed tavern with plenty of ranchlike decor, an outdoor patio & a popular weekend brunch.

result.formatted_address: 707 E Pine St, Seattle, WA 98122, USA
result.name: Linda's Tavern

reviews.text: We were disappointed that the security guy tonight who reads outside turned us way tonight with our dog. We used to frequent here because they were dog friendly, and were happy to come back after the new year. I wish we had known of the new policy change. Still a great Place to stop by for HH.

Legendary Local Watering Hole.
Good cocktails and Food.
Good rotation on the taps.

I've been coming to Linda's since 2018. I've always been satisfied with the level of service from the staff, the professionalism, and above all, the drinks and food.

Their grilled cheese sandwiches are simple, but have always surpassed my expectations--pair it with onion rings or fries (with a side of ranch). With both and indoor and door settings, in addition to the establishment being dog-friendly, I make a concerted effort to make sure I go there if I'm with friends.

Guy working the door was the rudest person I met during my vacation in Seattle. I get checking IDs and dealing with drunks isn't 'fun'. I know I've worked that job before.

However there is no reason you can offer some attempt to do your job without being a jerk. You're the first and last person people see when coming to this establishment.

As far as the rest of the place, it's an ok spot. The rest of the staff was friendly and the music was good. A couple arcade machines and an outdoor area. When I come back to Seattle I'll skip this spot

Eclectic little bar with great mixed drinks and great staff! We came too late to try the food, so we will have to come another for that. They let us bring a pizza from the place across the street while we were drinking, though, and that was truly appreciated. Great service, prices, and atmosphere! Definitely would recommend!

They did have outdoor seating, and they are restricting the numbers of guests in the outdoor area. They disinfect after every guest, which contributes to the longer wait time to get in. Masks required until you have your order, and every time the waitress/waiter comes up.

Linda's\u00a0Tavern.description: It’s not seedy enough to qualify as a full-fledged dive, but there’s something admirably durable and dive-like about Linda’s. It’s the wise, seen-it-all matron of Capitol Hill bars, decked out in country-western attire. Dogs are also welcomed. Check out Linda’s sister bar, King’s Hardware in Ballard, for a similar vibe and menu.

result.adr_address: 2332 2nd Ave, Seattle, WA 98121-1710, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Dark, clubby lounge where patrons sip classic & seasonal cocktails & tuck into small plates.

result.name: Rob Roy

reviews.text: Went there for the Christmas drinks. They were good but way expensive. Total bill came to $50 for 2 of us. Was also expecting a "pop up" to have holiday decor but there was nothing. Maybe they had taken it down as we visited after the 25th?

Friendly, knowledgeable, enthusiastic bartenders serving interesting and delicious cocktails - the menu was delightful, highly recommend the gunpowder punch, but they made great things off-menu to suit as well. The atmosphere leans intimate, which I enjoyed.

The house takes gratuity and takes 55% out to pay for benefits for the staff.

Imo that is a coat of doing business. Charge for the products don't steal the staff.

Also the menu was mediocre for house drinks and they couldn't make some basic cocktails if you order off menu.
A very cozy bar to catch up with friends while drinking quality curated libations. Friendly staff, clean facilities, knowledgeable folks, and appropriately pour bevvy's.

A longtime favorite in Belltown for a quality selection of cocktails in a comfortable setting. I enjoy the Up To Date cocktail (Rob Roy’s old fashioned) from the classics menu, but my favorite is their original Saffron Sandalwood Sour. 👌

Rob Roy.description: Can a bar be sophisticated and cozy at the same time? James Beard nominee Rob Roy achieves that rare equilibrium with artfully placed gentle lighting, elegant yet comfortable leather stools (with, let’s celebrate this, back support!) a den-like sofa area, and an ace lineup of impeccably composed drinks. A venerable figure in the rise of Seattle’s craft cocktail community, it’s been open since 2009 and hasn’t stagnated one bit. The special move here is porting contemporary techniques and ingredients into classic cocktails: Sherry and a river stone tincture give their martini alluring minerality, while pandan and aged rum fat-washed with coffee-infused butter boost the Jungle Bird right into the stratosphere. There’s also an equally great selection of signature newer-school drinks, and an intriguing menu of no-alcohol cocktails.

result.adr_address: 1923 7th Ave, Seattle, WA 98101-1207, USA
result.name: Phocific Standard Time

reviews.text: Feels like you're in a different country! Sweet little spot with great cocktails. The food is also great! Simple but excellent. Prices are also very reasonable, especially for the great quality here. This place will be on regular rotation for us.

Really great spot! We arrived shortly after 5pm and there were plenty of seats available. It did fill up fairly quickly though. The cocktails were very unique and well-made (try the tofu martini!) and the pho was excellent and arrived quickly. Not as many food options as the full restaurant downstairs (the food section on the menu is titled "snacks") but still enough for a meal. The cocktails were on the pricier side, in my opinion, but they were one-of-a-kind so it makes sense. Great vibes, good service, I'll come back to try more of the drinks!

Absolutely delicious cocktails made with very Southeast Asian focused ingredients. The pairings are so inspiring! Had to wait an hour to get in but definitely worth a visit. Go early to add your name to the waitlist, then circle back after dinner!

It’s a really quaint and all the dishes had amazing flavour you wouldn’t taste elsewhere. Banh bot loc is a tapioca wrapped savior tube wrapped bamboo leaf but the dip is by far the winner. So delicious!

Creative + strong drinks with a nice ambiance! We visited on a Friday night, and the wait was well over an hour. Would recommend visiting either earlier when the open or much later after dinner hours. We were seated at the bar, which had an intimate ambiance to watch the knowledgeable bartenders craft our drinks. Favorites were definitely the Ca Phe and Cua Dip!

Ca Phe Tini 5/5: So good!! Egg coffee with a thick velvelty foam layer. The alcohol content in it is paired very well with the coffee flavor. Would highly recommend!

La Dua 4/5: the subtle pandan flavor was brought out well with the hibiscus and the mezcal. I was particularly impressed as it tasted like real pandan, rather than artificial essence. This drink did have a very strong alcohol flavor, would order something else if you aren't  into that.

Cua Dip 5/5 -- the crab/prawn dip is so flavorful and very generous chunks of crab meat in it! Wish it came with more pieces or baguette to dip!

Phocific Standard Time.description: “Viet style tree house” Phocific Standard Time (PST) is an intimate bar up the stairs from Pho Bac’s downtown location that serves cocktails made with Vietnamese ingredients and flavors. Try the trung muoi, made with a pho fat–washed Japanese whisky, cream sherry, carcavelos wine, and salted egg yolk; or nuoc mat, a cocktail with soju, Cocchi Americano, logan, and citrus and jasmine flavors. Co-owner Yenvy Pham has whipped up a playful menu with offerings like a creamy, cheesy crab dip that perfectly compliments PST’s drinks.

result.adr_address: 2322 2nd Ave, Seattle, WA 98121-1710, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Multipurpose hub with a theater, basement bar, lounge, classic dining room & original 1920s decor.

result.name: The Rendezvous

reviews.text: Simple bar that’s kind of divey. If you’re looking for a holdover spot while waiting for a reservation, I actually think this is a really great option. It’s quiet enough to have a conversation and the drinks don’t break the bank. I would recommend d for someone looking to have a drink and catchup. I wouldn’t recommend this spot if you’re looking to rage or for this to be the sole purpose of the outing. I think it compliments the night’s plans.
Immaculate vibes. Made my favorite off menu drink with no complaints. Got to watch a movie without planning or paying for that experience.

Great venue.  I had no idea this place hosted such great artists.  My s.o. and I had a wonderful time listening to up and coming, super talented singers.

The venue is very private, the ambiance feels cozy and romantic.

The bartender was great, I got a paloma with mezcal and I really enjoyed it.

Very nice.

Great bar with different rooms for private events and gatherings. Really like their Jewelbox Theater. Our friend rented it to show Auntie Mame. The space in the basement is The Grotto. Nice and cozy... Good craft cocktails and a nice draft beer selection. They have events going on all the time. I've never eaten there, but they have a Naked Brunch (open mic) on Sundays. Looked interesting.

The host may have been the funniest dude there. A quaint little joint. We went to the 11pm show. You never know who is gonna show up. I heard Chris rock popped in the week before. I enjoy comedy clubs and in this district...its great.

The Rendezvous.description: The Rendezvous opened in 1927 as an exclusive restaurant, speakeasy, and screening room catering to the movie industry in Belltown’s Film Row, and then deteriorated into a seedy dive bar in the ’70s after the film industry moved on. Refurbished in 2001, it’s spent the past two decades as a main hub of Seattle’s fringe nightlife and features a menu of high-quality craft cocktails. It’s an effective middle ground between its previous identities: red carpet and chandelier atmosphere with a dive-bar heart.

result.adr_address: 2421 1st Ave, Seattle, WA 98121-1311, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Eclectic eats including burgers, tacos & hummus at a funky bar with offbeat art & weekend brunch.

result.name: Cyclops

reviews.text: Delicious spicy mango mezcal drink, not too sweet, real spice, well balanced. The Cesar salad was excellent (although fried corn bread croutons, while delicious, didn’t quite fit). Added chicken was moist, spicy, and delicious. I needed a place to hang out and recharge (figuratively, literally) in a calm place and this was perfect. The staff were chill, efficient, and convivial. I would highly recommend!

We stopped in for a quick drink to rehydrate after all the walking we'd done.  They have a respectable selection of cocktails. I was very surprised to pay $4 for a simple glass of Diet Pepsi. The cocktail we ordered was $12 and I was happy with it. It was tasty and I watched the bartender make it, so I know I got my money's worth. 😏
Great food!  The wait staff was amazing.  Super friendly and very helpful.  Get the polenta “tots”!  I could wait and was half way through before I took a picture.

This place exceeded my expectations! Such a fun atmosphere, delicious food (got the California burrito), and of course got the Pink Eye drink. Loved how it looked like an actual eyeball. I love places that can bring some fun into their place. The service was one of the best I've had in Belltown. Will definitely be back.

This was my first time here, and I was overall impressed with the atmosphere, food, and prices. The people were friendly, as well as the staff. The place was clean, and a great location. I had the barbecue sandwich with french fries, and it was very good.

Cyclops.description: Since 1990, this historic grunge bar/cafe has been luring customers in with its wise, winking neon eye gazing out upon First Avenue. Half diner and half dive, Cyclops is where the industry folks and old-guard Sub Poppers would hang out after shows at the nearby Croc or practice at Black Dog Forge around the corner — and where some still do. The food’s solid, the Rainier’s cold, the lamps are lava, the paintings are velvet, the dress code is hoodies and flannels. Get the crispy polenta fries.

result.adr_address: 2232 1st Ave, Seattle, WA 98121, USA

editorial_summary.overview: French-inspired hideaway serving inventive craft cocktails & nibbles in a quaint, cozy space.

result.name: Roquette

reviews.text:
After enjoying happy hour at Umi Sake, I always find myself drawn to this spot for a drink. The cozy ambiance is undeniably appealing, and I thoroughly enjoy the overall vibe. However, I must admit that every time I leave this place, I feel a little more than just tipsy - their old-fashioned cocktails are exceptionally potent and not for the faint of heart!
One aspect that bothers me about this place is the constant feeling of not being welcomed. The staff's lack of friendliness and accommodation adds to this sentiment.

If you're in Seattle and looking for a laid-back bar with delicious cocktails, look no further than Roquette in Belltown. We decided to grab a few drinks here after dinner one night and we weren't disappointed. The atmosphere was sophisticated yet comfortable—it had a dark, cozy aesthetic while still being especially lively. The cocktail menu had something to offer for everyone, so we felt spoiled for choice! We had a great time sipping our drinks and catching up on our night. I would highly recommend stopping by if you're in Seattle and in the mood for a chic spot with yummy drinks—it's a great option!

Me and my friends ordered the Panic Button which was recommended to us and I got to say this was a really interesting experience. The server was really welcoming and friendly. Didn't take long for our drinks. Upon taking a few sips, I already like the drink; then taking the seed and chewing it left a numb feeling (also really salty at first) but then following up with the drink was really unique. The taste and the vibe was really .  This is something I would recommend and would get again.

My partner and I came in on a slow Monday afternoon. The two gents who served us were delightful (Joe and Kevin..? Sorry gents). I asked for a non-alcoholic beverage and received a divine Pathfinder, grenadine, coffee concoction. She ordered a Chartreuse highball off of their happy hour menu.

Truly magnificent. Great service, awesome drinks, nice lil snackies, solid happy hour, and good company.

Ambiance was fantastic.  Service was great until.... they told us our 90 minutes of seating was up and we should move along.  They must've said that to other diners because the place evacuated and there were very few patrons left (you could count them on 1 hand). I found that odd. Seems a better business practice to keep people there to buy more drinks especially if there's no line of people dying to be seated.  But what do I know about business?  I guess it's better than being a dram shop issue.  Anyways, I'm off to try other places that might appreciate my business a bit more. It's worth going to.  Drinks were fine if you can drink them within 90 minutes.

Roquette.description: Zig Zag Cafe alum Erik Hakkinen opened Roquette in 2019, but it feels like it’s been here forever. The striking Marseille-blue storefront sets the classique tone, while tastefully plush seating, just-right lighting, and a prominent mural of a tropical vista establishes the interior atmosphere. The impeccably crafted cocktails often incorporate ingredients like Amontillado or Armagnac, and the affable bartenders are apt to eavesdrop and then pour you a sample of something you’ve expressed curiosity about. Just like the caviar-and-Bugles appetizer it offers on the snack menu, Roquette is fancy and approachable at the same time.

result.adr_address: 928 12th Ave, Seattle, WA 98122, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Snug bar serving aged spirits, bespoke drinks, global bites & more in a retro, bottle-adorned space.

result.name: canon

reviews.text:
I would highly recommend this place for fancy drinks, especially if you appreciate good cocktails.

Even though we arrived just minutes after they’d opened, the bar was already almost full, and the main seating area had some full tables too. We were lucky to get the last two seats at the bar.

Watching the bartenders craft the drinks was a show in and of itself. I ordered a “surprise me!” and it was good! The cool thing about it is that the bartender asks about your tastes, then makes you something based on them but doesn’t tell you what’s in the drink. So you enjoy a truly one of a kind drink.

The bread with fennel pollen and honey butter was excellent too. Would definitely go back here with friends or family visiting town or for a special occasion.

Always an exceptional experience.  The talent behind the bar is phenomenal.  Beyond creative with their ever changing offering of cocktails.  Cool new feature of the battle of two hotels. We ordered from each - Red Head, Scorpion, Come up & see me sometime, & Spirit of 76.  The bread is delicious and a great compliment to the cocktails.
Make a reservation, even if going early in the evening.
Embrace their creativity and try something new!

Finest bar ever! Expect the price, it’s fun to order their innovations:) some of them are really good and at least you think it’s good looking! lol. The taste so far, yes.

It’s kinda small place than I expected, but it’s not super crowded tho so you don’t need to make a reservation all the time.

The food ($40) and drink ($22) are expensive. But yes you will definitely get some nice experience here if you wanna have some good time.

Great bar with lots of variations and shapes of cocktails utensils.
For the food, the beef tartare is pretty good!
I would also recommend their whiskey based cocktails as well.

Although dishes and drinks here are rather expensive, it is still a recommended bar in the Capitol Hill area!

Drinks are very good! We also had the meat and cheese plate, also very nice and fresh. Atmosphere is busy, lots of people, difficult to really interact with the bartenders to get the drink for you.

Still recommend!

Canon.description: The term world-famous gets thrown around a lot, but Canon has appeared on best bars in the world lists, and not near the bottom. Boasting a 181-page list of spirits that includes decades-old vintage bottlings, the place is a veritable Smithsonian of booze, and the drinks are often as attention-grabbing as they are creative. A luxe food menu includes bites like Taylor Shellfish oysters and salmon tartare, as well as larger portions like lamb chops and steak.

result.adr_address: 1501 Western Ave Ste 202, Seattle, WA 98101, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Craft cocktails & gourmet snacks in a hip space tucked away by a staircase near Pike Place Market.

result.formatted_address: 1501 Western Ave Ste 202, Seattle, WA 98101, USA
result.name: Zig Zag Cafe

reviews.text:
A super cool restaurant with outstanding drinks and amazing food. Our entire experience here was fantastic and we will definitely be back next time we are in Seattle.

The cocktail menu was very creative which is something we really enjoy - it’s nice not just having your standard cocktails.

This is such an elegant hideaway from the hustle and bustle of the market and waterfront. A bit pricier than some places, but excellent drink menu and entrees are of high quality. Worth climbing the stairs and spending an hour or two. The happy hour menu shaves a buck or two off the regular menu, so don’t expect a deeper discount. Excellent knowledgeable service. Attentive.

First of all, know that they are still checking vaccine cards which is no problem for me.
As for the decoration and ambiance, it is great! It has the feel of a speakeasy or cool jazz club. And they have jazz playing to help with that.
I enjoyed the drinks very much. I had a Sassy Monk and my boyfriend had a Monet. Both tasted great to me.
Next for food we had hush puppies. They were very tasty but maybe a little over-salted.
For the main dishes I had the Smoky Beet tartar, which wasn't exactly what I was hoping for. I think the smokiness killed the beet flavor but it grew on me the more I ate it. And my boyfriend had the duck tostada. This was very tasty and well seasoned.
Finally I tried the bread pudding. I love bread pudding, but I wouldn't order this again. It has a mild flavor and the sauce that was with it was pretty bland as well.
Overall I enjoyed the feel of it there and liked that the menu offered some unique options and I would definitely go again.
And the waitress was very lovely!

Awesome drinks. The food was good too. I had the pork rinds, arancini and the bone barrow. The expresso martini was also really good. All super delicious! Def recommend this place if you are looking for a variety of drinks to try.

A unique experience hidden away in the heart of Seattle, Washington. Located in Pike Place Market, the servers are very helpful and courteous. The entire experience here is relaxing but in also feels different from many of the other cafes in the area.

Definitely check it out if you're in the area!

Drinks:
Chopin
Twilight in Boston

Zig Zag Cafe.description: You can’t know Seattle’s craft cocktail scene without knowing The Zig Zag. Famous for bartender Murray Stenson’s tenure, during which he reintroduced the world to the Last Word cocktail, it remains a top-notch bar even though Stenson has long moved on. Cocktails are detailed and composed, the staff is warmly hospitable, and the atmosphere combines moodily lit coziness with buzzy destination elegance.

result.adr_address: 700 3rd Ave, Seattle, WA 98104, USA

editorial_summary.overview: The Arctic Club's cocktail lounge pours upscale drinks amid stylish leather & velvet decor.

result.name: Polar Bar

reviews.text: Yes, this is the place Macklemore shot part of his music video Dance Off! Chill vibes, good drinks, and free-to-play pool tables. Loved the mirror tables. I had the Marie Antoinette cocktail which came with a little piece of cake 🍰 we also checked out the ballroom upstairs, which was absolutely stunning. Stand in the middle on the room on the dance floor and make some noise. You’re in for a sweet treat here.

Delightful! The cocktails are made with experience and themeing in mind, and we were pleased with the drinks! We highly recommend the charcuterie board; it's a little pricy, but the price is easily found in the excellent spread.

Polar Bar, the next secretly awesome bar in Seattle to get mobbed by hipsters! lol 🤷🏼‍♂️ But, that's👌🏼 a-okay for them, cause I'm sure the bartenders aren't going to complain!💰🥃🥂🍻💰  But, in the meantime, I've found the spot to be at after my week nights!  You walk in, there's no crowd, and you feel like your in some bar out of a movie.  And the wells are stellar!
Nice stiff drinks. Comfortable seating. Great for conversation.

Great and friendly bartenders.  Highly recommend visiting this bar if you are in the area.  Also be sure to try the Marie Antoinette as it was yummy. In this case you can have your cake and eat it too..

Polar Bar.description: Built in 1914 to host a social club for Arctic explorers, the Arctic Club Hotel is a Beaux-Arts masterwork and an architectural fave of locals and travelers alike — thanks in no small part to the iconic terracotta walruses on the facade. To boot, inside the expansive lobby is the snazzy blue-lit Polar Bar, definitely one of Seattle’s most beautiful bars. Longtime bar manager Mike has got all the dad jokes and specializes in the Smoke & Mirrors — basically a barbecued old-fashioned, made using the nifty little cocktail smoker and a bell jar. A lovely way to have some birthday drinks, kick off a sexy date, or just celebrate a personal victory.

result.adr_address: 2963 4th Ave S, Seattle, WA 98134-1914, USA
result.name: Orient Express

reviews.text: Fun atmosphere, good food, great service. The dinner special for 2 is actually affordable! Their hot n sour soup was delish. I wish my entre came with a little bit of rice. Environment is really cool when there's shows. Ive yet to try the karaoke but its on the list.

Honestly I really loved the Orient Express - it’s a weird place and those that like it will love it and those who don’t get it will probably never get it. They serve both American Chinese food as well as Thai food but honestly you’re probably not there for the food even though it’s not bad in that 80’s/90’s classic msg laden Chinese food vibe. We came for a birthday party in the karaoke rooms and also checked out the cocktail lounge and both were unique in a way that seems to be disappearing in Seattle.
Cool train cars, the interior is dark but fascinating, a little dingy. We got carry out. The food was fabulous. Well worth a visit, I will be back.

Super cool place! Food was delicious 😋. We went for lunch. Ordered the ginger scallion beef, soo good, lots of ginger. Crab Rangoon is delicious! Service was okay, rice was wrong and soup forgotten, but got it to go. Would eat here again.
Friendly fast service.  Hot and sour soup was very good. Egg roll was disappointing fried rice good general Tso chicken was good

Orient Express.description: Few things are as Seattle as a divey Chinese restaurant that’s also a bar (or is it a bar that’s also a restaurant?), and The Orient Express might be the most Seattle of ’em all. Housed in a series of train cars — one of which was ridden by FDR during his 1944 reelection campaign — with a half-century legacy as the local institution Andy’s Diner, The Orient Express’s setting has as much history as it has novelty. Drinks are simple and stiff, there’s karaoke on Thursdays, and if we’re lucky, someday the pre-pandemic disco dance nights will return.

result.adr_address: 4559 California Ave SW, Seattle, WA 98116, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Eclectic hangout stocking CDs & vinyl, plus a cafe serving American breakfasts, burgers & salads.

result.formatted_address: 4559 California Ave SW, Seattle, WA 98116, USA
result.name: Easy Street Records & Cafe

reviews.text: Easy Street is a super cool record store boasting lots of memorabilia, band shirts and of course vinyl. 👕🎶💽 They have so much to choose from. The staff are courteous and give you your space to browse. Just keep in mind that their vinyl is pricey 💲 around $40 for each individual record and greatest hits albums are even more expensive.

What a throw back! For those of us that actually grew up with record stores, you will love it! As well as those that didn't! Amazing selection! Cool vibe! Tap beer upstairs and café downstairs! DJ playing music... just the best experience!

Amazing record shop! Does awesome releases and concerts! Great swag and great. Cafe is classic diner fare with record shop flare! Amazing french toast and bacon! Full service espresso and alcohol bar! Staff are awesome! Great for kids! (Cafe open early, record shop/ bar open at 9.)

Absolutely amazing atmosphere! So many records and so much history. Prices are fair, better than online actually, and the staff was super helpful and welcoming. They let us search for records until the last min. Can't wait to go back! Thank you!

Easy Street is the coolest breakfast joint / bar / record store, I ever seen! We're here almost everyday for a week getting breakfast and coffee having a good times with good people. And to say I loved it would be an understatement. Thanks Mike and to all the easy Street employees for making my trip to Seattle that much more memorable!

Easy Street Records & Cafe.description: What’s more Seattle than a bar inside a record store? Especially one with a bunch of framed covers from The Rocket and a huge mural of Chris Cornell’s face? Out in the West Seattle Junction, Easy Street Records has been repping Seattle hard since the late ‘80s — a cafe was added to the shop in 2001, and since 2022, there’s been a teeny bar upstairs with menus on the backs of old 45s and punny cocktail names. It’s less of a bar in the sense of a room you can go inside of and more just the piece of furniture that is called a bar, but it’s no less a blast to pull up a stool behind the vinyl bins and have a Shirley Temple of the Dog. (That’s Olympia Vodka, grenadine, and lemon/lime soda.)

result.adr_address: 5613 4th Ave S, Seattle, WA 98108-2422, USA

editorial_summary.overview: Family-owned bar serving broasted chicken & pub grub since 1950, with TVs, a patio & a dance floor.

result.name: Marco Polo Bar & Grill

reviews.text: A really fun and lowkey bar in the SoDo neighborhood of Seattle. Great food and drinks, spacious with plenty of games to pass time. Will definitely revisit!

Great South Seattle establishment. Plenty of on street parking. The food is pub/bar fare done really well. I had a Blue cheese Bacon Burger that was absolutely mouthwatering awesome! The service was great. Really friendly helpful service. I really enjoyed the atmosphere. Great people. I'll definitely be back.

Chill sports bar with great food.  Friendly staff, fair prices.  People seemed to really enjoy the chicken.  It looked good.  I had a Ruben and it was delicious.  Had a tasty bloody Mary, too.
Update: karaoke is on! 🎤

I've never had a bad time at Marco Polo. This bar is a great spot to watch Coug football games. The chicken is a must here. So tender and juicy. They always have a great selection of beer on tap. This place is a genuinely great sports bar.

Marco Polo has real Broasted chicken—the best in town! It may well be the only place that serves Broasted chicken in town. It also serves my favorite beer, Manny’s. A friendly sports bar with good food, good service, and good beer is like what more do you want?!

Marco Polo Bar & Grill.description: This scrappy Georgetown roadhouse dates back to 1950, when Fourth Avenue South was part of Highway 99, but it can get overlooked these days. This is wrong to do, because the extra-crunchy Broasted™ chicken and jojos at Marco Polo are arguably the best in the whole entire Northwest — they’ve got that OG chicken-bucket pressure fryer with the big crank on top. (By the way, did you know that jojos are from the PNW? Well, they are!) The bar itself, meaning like the physical bar, is super charming too, all curved and swooshy and 1950s-ey. Fun spot for trivia and bingo. But yeah, it’s the fried chicken. Get that.
